##  [824] "difficult by the fact that Harry had grabbed Uncle Vernon around the"         
##  [825] "neck from behind. After a minute of confused fighting, in which"              
##  [826] "everyone got hit a lot by the Smelting stick, Uncle Vernon straightened"      
##  [827] "up, gasping for breath, with Harry's letter clutched in his"                  
##  [828] "hand.　　\"Go to your cupboard -- I mean, your bedroom,\" he wheezed at"      
##  [829] "Harry. \"Dudley -- go -- just go.\"　　Harry walked round and round his"      
##  [830] "new room. Someone knew he had moved out of his cupboard and they seemed"      
##  [831] "to know he hadn't received his first letter. Surely that meant they'd"        
##  [832] "try again? And this time he'd make sure they didn't fail. He had a"           
##  [833] "plan.　　The repaired alarm clock rang at six o'clock the next morning."      
##  [834] "Harry turned it off quickly and dressed silently. He mustn't wake the"        
##  [835] "Dursleys. He stole downstairs without turning on any of the"                  
##  [836] "lights.　　He was going to wait for the postman on the corner of Privet"      
##  [837] "Drive and get the letters for number four first. His heart hammered as"       
##  [838] "he crept across the dark hall toward the front door --　　Harry leapt"        
##  [839] "into the air; he'd trodden on something big and squashy on the doormat"       
##  [840] "-- something alive!　　Lights clicked on upstairs and to his horror"          
##  [841] "Harry realized that the big, squashy something had been his uncle's"          
##  [842] "face. Uncle Vernon had been lying at the foot of the front door in a"         
##  [843] "sleeping bag, clearly making sure that Harry didn't do exactly what"          
##  [844] "he'd been trying to do. He shouted at Harry for about half an hour and"       
##  [845] "then told him to go and make a cup of tea. Harry shuffled miserably off"      
##  [846] "into the kitchen and by the time he got back, the mail had arrived,"          
##  [847] "right into Uncle Vernon's lap. Harry could see three letters addressed"       
##  [848] "in green ink.　　I want --\" he began, but Uncle Vernon was tearing the"      
##  [849] "letters into pieces before his eyes. Uncle Vernon didnt go to work that"      
##  [850] "day. He stayed at home and nailed up the mail slot.　　\"See,\" he"           
##  [851] "explained to Aunt Petunia through a mouthful of nails, \"if they can't"       
##  [852] "deliver them they'll just give up.\"　　\"I'm not sure that'll work,"         
##  [853] "Vernon.\"　　\"Oh, these people's minds work in strange ways, Petunia,"       
##  [854] "they're not like you and me,\" said Uncle Vernon, trying to knock in a"       
##  [855] "nail with the piece of fruitcake Aunt Petunia had just brought"               
##  [856] "him.　　On Friday, no less than twelve letters arrived for Harry. As"         
##  [857] "they couldn't go through the mail slot they had been pushed under the"        
##  [858] "door, slotted through the sides, and a few even forced through the"           
##  [859] "small window in the downstairs bathroom.　　Uncle Vernon stayed at home"      
##  [860] "again. After burning all the letters, he got out a hammer and nails and"      
##  [861] "boarded up the cracks around the front and back doors so no one could"        
##  [862] "go out. He hummed \"Tiptoe Through the Tulips\" as he worked, and jumped"     
##  [863] "at small noises.　　On Saturday, things began to get out of hand."            
##  [864] "Twenty-four letters to Harry found their way into the house, rolled up"       
##  [865] "and hidden inside each of the two dozen eggs that their very confused"        
##  [866] "milkman had handed Aunt Petunia through the living room window. While"        
##  [867] "Uncle Vernon made furious telephone calls to the post office and the"         
##  [868] "dairy trying to find someone to complain to, Aunt Petunia shredded the"       
##  [869] "letters in her food processor.　　\"Who on earth wants to talk to you"        
##  [870] "this badly?\" Dudley asked Harry in amazement.　　On Sunday morning,"         
##  [871] "Uncle Vernon sat down at the breakfast table looking tired and rather"        
##  [872] "ill, but happy.　　\"No post on Sundays,\" he reminded them cheerfully as"    
##  [873] "he spread marmalade on his newspapers, \"no damn letters today"               
##  [874] "--\"　　Something came whizzing down the kitchen chimney as he spoke and"     
##  [875] "caught him sharply on the back of the head. Next moment, thirty or"           
##  [876] "forty letters came pelting out of the fireplace like bullets. The"            
##  [877] "Dursleys ducked, but Harry leapt into the air trying to catch"                
##  [878] "one.　　\"Out! OUT!\"　　Uncle Vernon seized Harry around the waist and"      
##  [879] "threw him into the hall. When Aunt Petunia and Dudley had run out with"       
##  [880] "their arms over their faces, Uncle Vernon slammed the door shut. They"        
##  [881] "could hear the letters still streaming into the room, bouncing off the"       
##  [882] "walls and floor.　　\"That does it,\" said Uncle Vernon, trying to speak"     
##  [883] "calmly but pulling great tufts out of his mustache at the same time. I"       
##  [884] "want you all back here in five minutes ready to leave. We're going"           
##  [885] "away. Just pack some clothes. No arguments!\"　　He looked so dangerous"      
##  [886] "with half his mustache missing that no one dared argue. Ten minutes"          
##  [887] "later they had wrenched their way through the boarded-up doors and were"      
##  [888] "in the car, speeding toward the highway. Dudley was sniffling in the"         
##  [889] "back seat; his father had hit him round the head for holding them up"         
##  [890] "while he tried to pack his television, VCR, and computer in his sports"       
##  [891] "bag.　　They drove. And they drove. Even Aunt Petunia didn't dare ask"        
##  [892] "where they were going. Every now and then Uncle Vernon would take a"          
##  [893] "sharp turn and drive in the opposite direction for a while. \"Shake'em"       
##  [894] "off... shake 'em off,\" he would mutter whenever he did this.　　They"        
##  [895] "didn't stop to eat or drink all day. By nightfall Dudley was howling."        
##  [896] "He'd never had such a bad day in his life. He was hungry, he'd missed"        
##  [897] "five television programs he'd wanted to see, and he'd never gone so"          
##  [898] "long without blowing up an alien on his computer.　　Uncle Vernon"            
##  [899] "stopped at last outside a gloomy-looking hotel on the outskirts of a"         
##  [900] "big city. Dudley and Harry shared a room with twin beds and damp, musty"      
##  [901] "sheets. Dudley snored but Harry stayed awake, sitting on the"                 
##  [902] "windowsill, staring down at the lights of passing cars and"                   
##  [903] "wondering....　　They ate stale cornflakes and cold tinned tomatoes on"       
##  [904] "toast for breakfast the next day. They had just finished when the owner"      
##  [905] "of the hotel came over to their table.　　\"'Scuse me, but is one of you"     
##  [906] "Mr. H. Potter? Only I got about an 'undred of these at the front"             
##  [907] "desk.\"　　She held up a letter so they could read the green ink"             
##  [908] "address:　　Mr. H. Potter　　Room 17　　Railview"                             
##  [909] "Hotel　　Cokeworth　　Harry made a grab for the letter but Uncle Vernon"      
##  [910] "knocked his hand out of the way. The woman stared.　　\"I'll take them,\""    
##  [911] "said Uncle Vernon, standing up quickly and following her from the"            
##  [912] "dining room.　　Wouldn't it be better just to go home, dear?\" Aunt"          
##  [913] "Petunia suggested timidly, hours later, but Uncle Vernon didn't seem to"      
##  [914] "hear her. Exactly what he was looking for, none of them knew. He drove"       
##  [915] "them into the middle of a forest, got out, looked around, shook his"          
##  [916] "head, got back in the car, and off they went again. The same thing"           
##  [917] "happened in the middle of a plowed field, halfway across a suspension"        
##  [918] "bridge, and at the top of a multilevel parking garage.　　\"Daddy's gone"     
##  [919] "mad, hasn't he?\" Dudley asked Aunt Petunia dully late that afternoon."       
##  [920] "Uncle Vernon had parked at the coast, locked them all inside the car,"        
##  [921] "and disappeared.　　It started to rain. Great drops beat on the roof of"      
##  [922] "the car. Dud ley sniveled.　　\"It's Monday,\" he told his mother. \"The"     
##  [923] "Great Humberto's on tonight. I want to stay somewhere with a"                 
##  [924] "television. \"　　Monday. This reminded Harry of something. If it was"        
##  [925] "Monday -- and you could usually count on Dudley to know the days the"         
##  [926] "week, because of television -- then tomorrow, Tuesday, was Harry's"           
##  [927] "eleventh birthday. Of course, his birthdays were never exactly fun --"        
##  [928] "last year, the Dursleys had given him a coat hanger and a pair of Uncle"      
##  [929] "Vernon's old socks. Still, you weren't eleven every day.　　Uncle"            
##  [930] "Vernon was back and he was smiling. He was also carrying a long, thin"        
##  [931] "package and didn't answer Aunt Petunia when she asked what he'd"              
##  [932] "bought.　　\"Found the perfect place!\" he said. \"Come on! Everyone"         
##  [933] "out!\"　　 It was very cold outside the car. Uncle Vernon was pointing"       
##  [934] "at what looked like a large rock way out at sea. Perched on top of the"       
##  [935] "rock was the most miserable little shack you could imagine. One thing"        
##  [936] "was certain, there was no television in there.　　\"Storm forecast for"       
##  [937] "tonight!\" said Uncle Vernon gleefully, clapping his hands together."         
##  [938] "\"And this gentleman's kindly agreed to lend us his boat!\"　　A"             
##  [939] "toothless old man came ambling up to them, pointing, with a rather"           
##  [940] "wicked grin, at an old rowboat bobbing in the iron-gray water below"          
##  [941] "them.　　\"I've already got us some rations,\" said Uncle Vernon, \"so all"   
##  [942] "aboard!\"　　It was freezing in the boat. Icy sea spray and rain crept"       
##  [943] "down their necks and a chilly wind whipped their faces. After what"           
##  [944] "seemed like hours they reached the rock, where Uncle Vernon, slipping"        
##  [945] "and sliding, led the way to the broken-down house.　　The inside was"         
##  [946] "horrible; it smelled strongly of seaweed, the wind whistled through the"      
##  [947] "gaps in the wooden walls, and the fireplace was damp and empty. There"        
##  [948] "were only two rooms.　　Uncle Vernon's rations turned out to be a bag"        
##  [949] "of chips each and four bananas. He tried to start a fire but the empty"       
##  [950] "chip bags just smoked and shriveled up.　　\"Could do with some of those"     
##  [951] "letters now, eh?\" he said cheerfully.　　He was in a very good mood."        
##  [952] "Obviously he thought nobody stood a chance of reaching them here in a"        
##  [953] "storm to deliver mail. Harry privately agreed, though the thought"            
##  [954] "didn't cheer him up at all.　　As night fell, the promised storm blew"        
##  [955] "up around them. Spray from the high waves splattered the walls of the"        
##  [956] "hut and a fierce wind rattled the filthy windows. Aunt Petunia found a"       
##  [957] "few moldy blankets in the second room and made up a bed for Dudley on"        
##  [958] "the moth-eaten sofa. She and Uncle Vernon went off to the lumpy bed"          
##  [959] "next door, and Harry was left to find the softest bit of floor he could"      
##  [960] "and to curl up under the thinnest, most ragged blanket.　　The storm"         
##  [961] "raged more and more ferociously as the night went on. Harry couldn't"         
##  [962] "sleep. He shivered and turned over, trying to get comfortable, his"           
##  [963] "stomach rumbling with hunger. Dudley's snores were drowned by the low"        
##  [964] "rolls of thunder that started near midnight. The lighted dial of"             
##  [965] "Dudley's watch, which was dangling over the edge of the sofa on his fat"      
##  [966] "wrist, told Harry he'd be eleven in ten minutes' time. He lay and"            
##  [967] "watched his birthday tick nearer, wondering if the Dursleys would"            
##  [968] "remember at all, wondering where the letter writer was now.　　Five"          
##  [969] "minutes to go. Harry heard something creak outside. He hoped the roof"        
##  [970] "wasn't going to fall in, although he might be warmer if it did. Four"         
##  [971] "minutes to go. Maybe the house in Privet Drive would be so full of"           
##  [972] "letters when they got back that he'd be able to steal one"                    
##  [973] "somehow.　　Three minutes to go. Was that the sea, slapping hard on the"      
##  [974] "rock like that? And (two minutes to go) what was that funny crunching"        
##  [975] "noise? Was the rock crumbling into the sea?　　One minute to go and"          
##  [976] "he'd be eleven. Thirty seconds... twenty ... ten... nine -- maybe he'd"       
##  [977] "wake Dudley up, just to annoy him -- three... two..."                         
##  [978] "one...　　BOOM.　　The whole shack shivered and Harry sat bolt upright,"      
##  [979] "staring at the door. Someone was outside, knocking to come in.　　 THE"       
##  [980] "KEEPER OF THE KEYS　　BOOM. They knocked again. Dudley jerked awake."         
##  [981] "\"Where's the cannon?\" he said stupidly.　　There was a crash behind"        
##  [982] "them and Uncle Vernon came skidding into the room. He was holding a"          
##  [983] "rifle in his hands -- now they knew what had been in the long, thin"          
##  [984] "package he had brought with them.　　\"Who's there?\" he shouted. \"I warn"   
##  [985] "you -- I'm armed!\"　　There was a pause. Then --　　SMASH!　　The door"      
##  [986] "was hit with such force that it swung clean off its hinges and with a"        
##  [987] "deafening crash landed flat on the floor.　　A giant of a man was"            
##  [988] "standing in the doorway. His face was almost completely hidden by a"          
##  [989] "long, shaggy mane of hair and a wild, tangled beard, but you could make"      
##  [990] "out his eyes, glinting like black beetles under all the hair.　　The"         
##  [991] "giant squeezed his way into the hut, stooping so that his head just"          
##  [992] "brushed the ceiling. He bent down, picked up the door, and fitted it"         
##  [993] "easily back into its frame. The noise of the storm outside dropped a"         
##  [994] "little. He turned to look at them all.　　\"Couldn't make us a cup o'"        
##  [995] "tea, could yeh? It's not been an easy journey...\"　　He strode over to"      
##  [996] "the sofa where Dudley sat frozen with fear.　　\"Budge up, yeh great"         
##  [997] "lump,\" said the stranger.　　Dudley squeaked and ran to hide behind his"     
##  [998] "mother, who was crouching, terrified, behind Uncle Vernon.　　\"An'"          
##  [999] "here's Harry!\" said the giant.　　Harry looked up into the fierce,"          
## [1000] "wild, shadowy face and saw that the beetle eyes were crinkled in a"           
## [1001] "smile.　　\"Las' time I saw you, you was only a baby,\" said the giant."      
## [1002] "\"Yeh look a lot like yet dad, but yeh've got yet mom's eyes.\"　　Uncle"     
## [1003] "Vernon made a funny rasping noise.　　I demand that you leave at once,"       
## [1004] "sit!\" he said. \"You are breaking and entering!\"　　\"Ah, shut up,"         
## [1005] "Dursley, yeh great prune,\" said the giant; he reached over the back of"      
## [1006] "the sofa, jerked the gun out of Uncle Vernon's hands, bent it into a"         
## [1007] "knot as easily as if it had been made of rubber, and threw it into a"         
## [1008] "corner of the room.　　Uncle Vernon made another funny noise, like a"         
## [1009] "mouse being trodden on.　　\"Anyway -- Harry,\" said the giant, turning"      
## [1010] "his back on the Dursleys, \"a very happy birthday to yeh. Got summat fer"     
## [1011] "yeh here -- I mighta sat on it at some point, but it'll taste all"            
## [1012] "right.\"　　From an inside pocket of his black overcoat he pulled a"          
## [1013] "slightly squashed box. Harry opened it with trembling fingers. Inside"        
## [1014] "was a large, sticky chocolate cake with Happy Birthday Harry written on"      
## [1015] "it in green icing.　　Harry looked up at the giant. He meant to say"          
## [1016] "thank you, but the words got lost on the way to his mouth, and what he"       
## [1017] "said instead was, \"Who are you?\"　　The giant chuckled.　　\"True, I"       
## [1018] "haven't introduced meself. Rubeus Hagrid, Keeper of Keys and Grounds at"      
## [1019] "Hogwarts.\"　　He held out an enormous hand and shook Harry's whole"          
## [1020] "arm.　　\"What about that tea then, eh?\" he said, rubbing his hands"         
## [1021] "together. \"I'd not say no ter summat stronger if yeh've got it,"             
## [1022] "mind.\"　　His eyes fell on the empty grate with the shriveled chip bags"     
## [1023] "in it and he snorted. He bent down over the fireplace; they couldn't"         
## [1024] "see what he was doing but when he drew back a second later, there was a"      
## [1025] "roaring fire there. It filled the whole damp hut with flickering light"       
## [1026] "and Harry felt the warmth wash over him as though he'd sunk into a hot"       
## [1027] "bath.　　The giant sat back down on the sofa, which sagged under his"         
## [1028] "weight, and began taking all sorts of things out of the pockets of his"       
## [1029] "coat: a copper kettle, a squashy package of sausages, a poker, a"             
## [1030] "teapot, several chipped mugs, and a bottle of some amber liquid that he"      
## [1031] "took a swig from before starting to make tea. Soon the hut was full of"       
## [1032] "the sound and smell of sizzling sausage. Nobody said a thing while the"       
## [1033] "giant was working, but as he slid the first six fat, juicy, slightly"         
## [1034] "burnt sausages from the poker, Dudley fidgeted a little. Uncle Vernon"        
## [1035] "said sharply, \"Don't touch anything he gives you, Dudley.\"　　The giant"    
## [1036] "chuckled darkly.　　\"Yet great puddin' of a son don' need fattenin'"         
## [1037] "anymore, Dursley, don' worry.\"　　He passed the sausages to Harry, who"      
## [1038] "was so hungry he had never tasted anything so wonderful, but he still"        
## [1039] "couldn't take his eyes off the giant. Finally, as nobody seemed about"        
## [1040] "to explain anything, he said, \"I'm sorry, but I still don't really know"     
## [1041] "who you are.\"　　The giant took a gulp of tea and wiped his mouth with"      
## [1042] "the back of his hand.　　\"Call me Hagrid,\" he said, \"everyone does. An'"   
## [1043] "like I told yeh, I'm Keeper of Keys at Hogwarts -- yeh'll know all"           
## [1044] "about Hogwarts, o' course.　　\"Er -- no,\" said Harry.　　Hagrid looked"     
## [1045] "shocked.　　\"Sorry,\" Harry said quickly.　　\"Sony?\" barked Hagrid,"       
## [1046] "turning to stare at the Dursleys, who shrank back into the shadows."          
## [1047] "\"It' s them as should be sorry! I knew yeh weren't gettin' yer letters"      
## [1048] "but I never thought yeh wouldn't even know abou' Hogwarts, fer cryin'"        
## [1049] "out loud! Did yeh never wonder where yet parents learned it"                  
## [1050] "all?\"　　\"All what?\" asked Harry.　　\"ALL WHAT?\" Hagrid thundered. \"Now"
## [1051] "wait jus' one second!\"　　He had leapt to his feet. In his anger he"         
## [1052] "seemed to fill the whole hut. The Dursleys were cowering against the"         
## [1053] "wall.　　\"Do you mean ter tell me,\" he growled at the Dursleys, \"that"     
## [1054] "this boy -- this boy! -- knows nothin' abou' -- about"                        
## [1055] "ANYTHING?\"　　Harry thought this was going a bit far. He had been to"        
## [1056] "school, after all, and his marks weren't bad.　　\"I know some things,\""     
## [1057] "he said. \"I can, you know, do math and stuff.\" But Hagrid simply waved"     
## [1058] "his hand and said, \"About our world, I mean. Your world. My world. Yer"      
## [1059] "parents' world.\"　　\"What world?\"　　Hagrid looked as if he was about"     
## [1060] "to explode.　　\"DURSLEY!\" he boomed.　　Uncle Vernon, who had gone very"    
## [1061] "pale, whispered something that sounded like \"Mimblewimble.\" Hagrid"         
## [1062] "stared wildly at Harry.　　\"But yeh must know about yet mom and dad,\""      
## [1063] "he said. \"I mean, they're famous. You're famous.\"　　\"What? My -- my"      
## [1064] "mom and dad weren't famous, were they?\"　　\"Yeh don' know... yeh don'"      
## [1065] "know...\" Hagrid ran his fingers through his hair, fixing Harry with a"       
## [1066] "bewildered stare.　　\"Yeh don' know what yeh are?\" he said"                 
## [1067] "finally.　　Uncle Vernon suddenly found his voice.　　\"Stop!\" he"           
## [1068] "commanded. \"Stop right there, sit! I forbid you to tell the boy"             
## [1069] "anything!\"　　A braver man than Vernon Dursley would have quailed under"     
## [1070] "the furious look Hagrid now gave him; when Hagrid spoke, his every"           
## [1071] "syllable trembled with rage.　　\"You never told him? Never told him"         
## [1072] "what was in the letter Dumbledore left fer him? I was there! I saw"           
## [1073] "Dumbledore leave it, Dursley! An' you've kept it from him all these"          
## [1074] "years?\"　　\"Kept what from me?\" said Harry eagerly.　　\"STOP! I FORBID"   
## [1075] "YOU!\" yelled Uncle Vernon in panic.　　Aunt Petunia gave a gasp of"          
## [1076] "horror.　　\"Ah, go boil yet heads, both of yeh,\" said Hagrid. \"Harry --"   
## [1077] "yet a wizard.\"　　There was silence inside the hut. Only the sea and"        
## [1078] "the whistling wind could be heard.　　\"-- a what?\" gasped Harry.　　\"A"    
## [1079] "wizard, o' course,\" said Hagrid, sitting back down on the sofa, which"       
## [1080] "groaned and sank even lower, \"an' a thumpin' good'un, I'd say, once"         
## [1081] "yeh've been trained up a bit. With a mum an' dad like yours, what else"       
## [1082] "would yeh be? An' I reckon it's abou' time yeh read yer"                      
## [1083] "letter.\"　　Harry stretched out his hand at last to take the yellowish"      
## [1084] "envelope, addressed in emerald green to Mr. H. Potter, The Floor,"            
## [1085] "Hut-on-the-Rock, The Sea. He pulled out the letter and"                       
## [1086] "read:　　HOGWARTS SCHOOL of WITCHCRAFT and WIZARDRY　　Headmaster:"           
## [1087] "ALBUS DUMBLEDORE　　(Order of Merlin, First Class, Grand Sorc., Chf."         
## [1088] "Warlock, Supreme Mugwump, International Confed. of Wizards)　　Dear Mr."      
## [1089] "Potter,　　We are pleased to inform you that you have been accepted at"       
## [1090] "Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. Please find enclosed a list"      
## [1091] "of all necessary books and equipment.　　Term begins on September 1. We"      
## [1092] "await your owl by no later than July 31. Yours sincerely,　　Minerva"         
## [1093] "McGonagall,　　Deputy Headmistress　　Questions exploded inside Harry's"      
## [1094] "head like fireworks and he couldn't decide which to ask first. After a"       
## [1095] "few minutes he stammered, \"What does it mean, they await my"                 
## [1096] "owl?\"　　\"Gallopin' Gorgons, that reminds me,\" said Hagrid, clapping a"    
## [1097] "hand to his forehead with enough force to knock over a cart horse, and"       
## [1098] "from yet another pocket inside his overcoat he pulled an owl -- a real,"      
## [1099] "live, rather ruffled-looking owl -- a long quill, and a roll of"              
## [1100] "parchment. With his tongue between his teeth he scribbled a note that"        
## [1101] "Harry could read upside down:　　Dear Professor Dumbledore,　　Given"         
## [1102] "Harry his letter.　　Taking him to buy his things"                            
## [1103] "tomorrow.　　Weather's horrible. Hope you're Well.　　Hagrid　　Hagrid"       
## [1104] "rolled up the note, gave it to the owl, which clamped it in its beak,"        
## [1105] "went to the door, and threw the owl out into the storm. Then he came"         
## [1106] "back and sat down as though this was as normal as talking on the"             
## [1107] "telephone.　　Harry realized his mouth was open and closed it"                
## [1108] "quickly.　　\"Where was I?\" said Hagrid, but at that moment, Uncle"          
## [1109] "Vernon, still ashen-faced but looking very angry, moved into the"             
## [1110] "firelight.　　\"He's not going,\" he said.　　Hagrid grunted.　　\"I'd"       
## [1111] "like ter see a great Muggle like you stop him,\" he said.　　\"A what?\""     
## [1112] "said Harry, interested.　　\"A Muggle,\" said Hagrid, \"it's what we call"    
## [1113] "nonmagic folk like thern. An' it's your bad luck you grew up in a"            
## [1114] "family o' the biggest Muggles I ever laid eyes on.\"　　\"We swore when"      
## [1115] "we took him in we'd put a stop to that rubbish,\" said Uncle Vernon,"         
## [1116] "\"swore we'd stamp it out of him! Wizard indeed!\"　　\"You knew?\" said"     
## [1117] "Harry. \"You knew I'm a -- a wizard?\"　　\"Knew!\" shrieked Aunt Petunia"    
## [1118] "suddenly. \"Knew! Of course we knew! How could you not be, my dratted"        
## [1119] "sister being what she was? Oh, she got a letter just like that and"           
## [1120] "disappeared off to that-that school-and came home every vacation with"        
## [1121] "her pockets full of frog spawn, turning teacups into rats. I was the"         
## [1122] "only one who saw her for what she was -- a freak! But for my mother and"      
## [1123] "father, oh no, it was Lily this and Lily that, they were proud of"            
## [1124] "having a witch in the family!\"　　She stopped to draw a deep breath and"     
## [1125] "then went ranting on. It seemed she had been wanting to say all this"         
## [1126] "for years.　　\"Then she met that Potter at school and they left and got"     
## [1127] "married and had you, and of course I knew you'd be just the same, just"       
## [1128] "as strange, just as -- as -- abnormal -- and then, if you please, she"        
## [1129] "went and got herself blown up and we got landed with you!\"　　Harry had"     
## [1130] "gone very white. As soon as he found his voice he said, \"Blown up? You"      
## [1131] "told me they died in a car crash!\"　　\"CAR CRASH!\" roared Hagrid,"         
## [1132] "jumping up so angrily that the Dursleys scuttled back to their corner."       
## [1133] "\"How could a car crash kill Lily an' James Potter? It's an outrage! A"       
## [1134] "scandal! Harry Potter not knowin' his own story when every kid in our"        
## [1135] "world knows his name!\" \"But why? What happened?\" Harry asked"              
## [1136] "urgently.　　The anger faded from Hagrid's face. He looked suddenly"          
## [1137] "anxious.　　\"I never expected this,\" he said, in a low, worried voice."     
## [1138] "\"I had no idea, when Dumbledore told me there might be trouble gettin'"      
## [1139] "hold of yeh, how much yeh didn't know. Ah, Harry, I don' know if I'm"         
## [1140] "the right person ter tell yeh -- but someone 3 s gotta -- yeh can't go"       
## [1141] "off ter Hogwarts not knowin'.\"　　He threw a dirty look at the"              
## [1142] "Dursleys.　　\"Well, it's best yeh know as much as I can tell yeh --"         
## [1143] "mind, I can't tell yeh everythin', it's a great myst'ry, parts of"            
## [1144] "it....\"　　He sat down, stared into the fire for a few seconds, and"         
## [1145] "then said, \"It begins, I suppose, with -- with a person called -- but"       
## [1146] "it's incredible yeh don't know his name, everyone in our world knows"         
## [1147] "--\"　　\"Who? \"　　\"Well -- I don' like sayin' the name if I can help"     
## [1148] "it. No one does.\"　　\"Why not?\"　　\"Gulpin' gargoyles, Harry, people"     
## [1149] "are still scared. Blimey, this is difficult. See, there was this wizard"      
## [1150] "who went... bad. As bad as you could go. Worse. Worse than worse. His"        
## [1151] "name was...\"　　Hagrid gulped, but no words came out.　　\"Could you"        
## [1152] "write it down?\" Harry suggested.　　\"Nah -can't spell it. All right --"     
## [1153] "Voldemort. \" Hagrid shuddered. \"Don' make me say it again. Anyway, this"    
## [1154] "-- this wizard, about twenty years ago now, started lookin' fer"              
## [1155] "followers. Got 'em, too -- some were afraid, some just wanted a bit o'"       
## [1156] "his power, 'cause he was gettin' himself power, all right. Dark days,"        
## [1157] "Harry. Didn't know who ter trust, didn't dare get friendly with strange"      
## [1158] "wizards or witches... terrible things happened. He was takin' over."          
## [1159] "'Course, some stood up to him -- an' he killed 'em. Horribly. One o'"         
## [1160] "the only safe places left was Hogwarts. Reckon Dumbledore's the only"         
## [1161] "one You-Know-Who was afraid of. Didn't dare try takin' the school, not"       
## [1162] "jus' then, anyway.　　\"Now, yer mum an' dad were as good a witch an'"        
## [1163] "wizard as I ever knew. Head boy an' girl at Hogwarts in their day!"           
## [1164] "Suppose the myst'ry is why You-Know-Who never tried to get 'em on his"        
## [1165] "side before... probably knew they were too close ter Dumbledore ter"          
## [1166] "want anythin' ter do with the Dark Side.　　\"Maybe he thought he could"      
## [1167] "persuade 'em... maybe he just wanted 'em outta the way. All anyone"           
## [1168] "knows is, he turned up in the village where you was all living, on"           
## [1169] "Halloween ten years ago. You was just a year old. He came ter yer house"      
## [1170] "an' -- an' --\"　　Hagrid suddenly pulled out a very dirty, spotted"          
## [1171] "handkerchief and blew his nose with a sound like a foghorn.　　\"Sorry,\""    
## [1172] "he said. \"But it's that sad -- knew yer mum an' dad, an' nicer people"       
## [1173] "yeh couldn't find -- anyway...\"　　\"You-Know-Who killed 'em. An' then"      
## [1174] "-- an' this is the real myst'ry of the thing -- he tried to kill you,"        
## [1175] "too. Wanted ter make a clean job of it, I suppose, or maybe he just"          
## [1176] "liked killin' by then. But he couldn't do it. Never wondered how you"         
## [1177] "got that mark on yer forehead? That was no ordinary cut. That's what"         
## [1178] "yeh get when a Powerful, evil curse touches yeh -- took care of yer mum"      
## [1179] "an' dad an' yer house, even -- but it didn't work on you, an' that's"         
## [1180] "why yer famous, Harry. No one ever lived after he decided ter kill 'em,"      
## [1181] "no one except you, an' he'd killed some o' the best witches an' wizards"      
## [1182] "of the age -- the McKinnons, the Bones, the Prewetts -- an' you was"          
## [1183] "only a baby, an' you lived.\"　　Something very painful was going on in"      
## [1184] "Harry's mind. As Hagrid's story came to a close, he saw again the"            
## [1185] "blinding flash of green light, more clearly than he had ever remembered"      
## [1186] "it before -- and he remembered something else, for the first time in"         
## [1187] "his life: a high, cold, cruel laugh.　　Hagrid was watching him"              
## [1188] "sadly.　　\"Took yeh from the ruined house myself, on Dumbledore's"           
## [1189] "orders. Brought yeh ter this lot...\"　　\"Load of old tosh,\" said Uncle"    
## [1190] "Vernon. Harry jumped; he had almost forgotten that the Dursleys were"         
## [1191] "there. Uncle Vernon certainly seemed to have got back his courage. He"        
## [1192] "was glaring at Hagrid and his fists were clenched.　　\"Now, you listen"      
## [1193] "here, boy,\" he snarled, \"I accept there's something strange about you,"     
## [1194] "probably nothing a good beating wouldn't have cured -- and as for all"        
## [1195] "this about your parents, well, they were weirdos, no denying it, and"         
## [1196] "the world's better off without them in my opinion -- asked for all they"      
## [1197] "got, getting mixed up with these wizarding types -- just what I"              
## [1198] "expected, always knew they'd come to a sticky end --\"　　But at that"        
## [1199] "moment, Hagrid leapt from the sofa and drew a battered pink umbrella"         
## [1200] "from inside his coat. Pointing this at Uncle Vernon like a sword, he"         
## [1201] "said, \"I'm warning you, Dursley -I'm warning you -- one more word..."        
## [1202] "\"　　In danger of being speared on the end of an umbrella by a bearded"      
## [1203] "giant, Uncle Vernon's courage failed again; he flattened himself"             
## [1204] "against the wall and fell silent.　　\"That's better,\" said Hagrid,"         
## [1205] "breathing heavily and sitting back down on the sofa, which this time"         
## [1206] "sagged right down to the floor.　　Harry, meanwhile, still had"               
## [1207] "questions to ask, hundreds of them.　　\"But what happened to Vol--,"         
## [1208] "sorry -- I mean, You-Know-Who?\"　　\"Good question, Harry. Disappeared."     
## [1209] "Vanished. Same night he tried ter kill you. Makes yeh even more famous."      
## [1210] "That's the biggest myst'ry, see... he was gettin' more an' more"              
## [1211] "powerful -- why'd he go?　　\"Some say he died. Codswallop, in my"            
## [1212] "opinion. Dunno if he had enough human left in him to die. Some say he's"      
## [1213] "still out there, bidin' his time, like, but I don' believe it. People"        
## [1214] "who was on his side came back ter ours. Some of 'em came outta kinda"         
## [1215] "trances. Don~ reckon they could've done if he was comin' back.　　\"Most"     
## [1216] "of us reckon he's still out there somewhere but lost his powers. Too"         
## [1217] "weak to carry on. 'Cause somethin' about you finished him, Harry. There"      
## [1218] "was somethin' goin' on that night he hadn't counted on -- I dunno what"       
## [1219] "it was, no one does -- but somethin' about you stumped him, all"              
## [1220] "right.\"　　Hagrid looked at Harry with warmth and respect blazing in"        
## [1221] "his eyes, but Harry, instead of feeling pleased and proud, felt quite"        
## [1222] "sure there had been a horrible mistake. A wizard? Him? How could he"          
## [1223] "possibly be? He'd spent his life being clouted by Dudley, and bullied"        
## [1224] "by Aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon; if he was really a wizard, why hadn't"      
## [1225] "they been turned into warty toads every time they'd tried to lock him"        
## [1226] "in his cupboard? If he'd once defeated the greatest sorcerer in the"          
## [1227] "world, how come Dudley had always been able to kick him around like a"        
## [1228] "football?　　\"Hagrid,\" he said quietly, \"I think you must have made a"     
## [1229] "mistake. I don't think I can be a wizard.\"　　To his surprise, Hagrid"       
## [1230] "chuckled.　　\"Not a wizard, eh? Never made things happen when you was"       
## [1231] "scared or angry?\"　　Harry looked into the fire. Now he came to think"       
## [1232] "about it... every odd thing that had ever made his aunt and uncle"            
## [1233] "furious with him had happened when he, Harry, had been upset or"              
## [1234] "angry... chased by Dudley's gang, he had somehow found himself out of"        
## [1235] "their reach... dreading going to school with that ridiculous haircut,"        
## [1236] "he'd managed to make it grow back... and the very last time Dudley had"       
## [1237] "hit him, hadn't he got his revenge, without even realizing he was doing"      
## [1238] "it? Hadn't he set a boa constrictor on him?　　Harry looked back at"          
## [1239] "Hagrid, smiling, and saw that Hagrid was positively beaming at"               
## [1240] "him.　　\"See?\" said Hagrid. \"Harry Potter, not a wizard -- you wait,"      
## [1241] "you'll be right famous at Hogwarts.\"　　But Uncle Vernon wasn't going"       
## [1242] "to give in without a fight.　　\"Haven't I told you he's not going?\" he"     
## [1243] "hissed. \"He's going to Stonewall High and he'll be grateful for it."         
## [1244] "I've read those letters and he needs all sorts of rubbish -- spell"           
## [1245] "books and wands and --\"　　\"If he wants ter go, a great Muggle like you"    
## [1246] "won't stop him,\" growled Hagrid. \"Stop Lily an' James Potter' s son"        
## [1247] "goin' ter Hogwarts! Yer mad. His name's been down ever since he was"          
## [1248] "born. He's off ter the finest school of witchcraft and wizardry in the"       
## [1249] "world. Seven years there and he won't know himself. He'll be with"            
## [1250] "youngsters of his own sort, fer a change, an' he'll be under the"             
## [1251] "greatest headmaster Hogwarts ever had Albus Dumbled--\"　　\"I AM NOT"        
## [1252] "PAYING FOR SOME CRACKPOT OLD FOOL To TEACH HIM MAGIC TRICKS!\" yelled"        
## [1253] "Uncle Vernon.　　But he had finally gone too far. Hagrid seized his"          
## [1254] "umbrella and whirled it over his head, \"NEVER,\" he thundered, \"-"          
## [1255] "INSULT- ALBUS- DUMBLEDORE- IN- FRONT- OF- ME!\"　　He brought the"            
## [1256] "umbrella swishing down through the air to point at Dudley -- there was"       
## [1257] "a flash of violet light, a sound like a firecracker, a sharp squeal,"         
## [1258] "and the next second, Dudley was dancing on the spot with his hands"           
## [1259] "clasped over his fat bottom, howling in pain. When he turned his back"        
## [1260] "on them, Harry saw a curly pig's tail poking through a hole in his"           
## [1261] "trousers.　　Uncle Vernon roared. Pulling Aunt Petunia and Dudley into"       
## [1262] "the other room, he cast one last terrified look at Hagrid and slammed"        
## [1263] "the door behind them.　　Hagrid looked down at his umbrella and stroked"      
## [1264] "his beard.　　\"Shouldn'ta lost me temper,\" he said ruefully, \"but it"      
## [1265] "didn't work anyway. Meant ter turn him into a pig, but I suppose he was"      
## [1266] "so much like a pig anyway there wasn't much left ter do.\"　　He cast a"      
## [1267] "sideways look at Harry under his bushy eyebrows.　　\"Be grateful if yeh"     
## [1268] "didn't mention that ter anyone at Hogwarts,\" he said. \"I'm -- er -- not"    
## [1269] "supposed ter do magic, strictly speakin'. I was allowed ter do a bit"         
## [1270] "ter follow yeh an' get yer letters to yeh an' stuff -- one o' the"            
## [1271] "reasons I was so keen ter take on the job　　\"Why aren't you supposed"       
## [1272] "to do magic?\" asked Harry.　　\"Oh, well -- I was at Hogwarts meself but"    
## [1273] "I -- er -- got expelled, ter tell yeh the truth. In me third year. They"      
## [1274] "snapped me wand in half an' everything. But Dumbledore let me stay on"        
## [1275] "as gamekeeper. Great man, Dumbledore.\" \"Why were you"                       
## [1276] "expelled?\"　　\"It's gettin' late and we've got lots ter do tomorrow,\""     
## [1277] "said Hagrid loudly. \"Gotta get up ter town, get all yer books an'"           
## [1278] "that.\"　　He took off his thick black coat and threw it to"                  
## [1279] "Harry.　　\"You can kip under that,\" he said. \"Don' mind if it wriggles"    
## [1280] "a bit, I think I still got a couple o' dormice in one o' the"                 
## [1281] "pockets.\"　　 DIAGON ALLEY　　Harry woke early the next morning."            
## [1282] "Although he could tell it was daylight, he kept his eyes shut"                
## [1283] "tight.　　\"It was a dream, he told himself firmly. \"I dreamed a giant"      
## [1284] "called Hagrid came to tell me I was going to a school for wizards. When"      
## [1285] "I open my eyes I'll be at home in my cupboard.\"　　There was suddenly a"     
## [1286] "loud tapping noise.　　And there's Aunt Petunia knocking on the door,"        
## [1287] "Harry thought, his heart sinking. But he still didn't open his eyes. It"      
## [1288] "had been such a good dream.　　Tap. Tap. Tap.　　\"All right,\" Harry"        
## [1289] "mumbled, \"I'm getting up.\"　　He sat up and Hagrid's heavy coat fell"       
## [1290] "off him. The hut was full of sunlight, the storm was over, Hagrid"            
## [1291] "himself was asleep on the collapsed sofa, and there was an owl rapping"       
## [1292] "its claw on the window, a newspaper held in its beak.　　Harry"               
## [1293] "scrambled to his feet, so happy he felt as though a large balloon was"        
## [1294] "swelling inside him. He went straight to the window and jerked it open."      
## [1295] "The owl swooped in and dropped the newspaper on top of Hagrid, who"           
## [1296] "didn't wake up. The owl then fluttered onto the floor and began to"           
## [1297] "attack Hagrid's coat.　　\"Don't do that.\"　　Harry tried to wave the"       
## [1298] "owl out of the way, but it snapped its beak fiercely at him and carried"      
## [1299] "on savaging the coat.　　\"Hagrid!\" said Harry loudly. \"There's an"         
## [1300] "owl　　\"Pay him,\" Hagrid grunted into the sofa.　　\"What?\"　　\"He wants" 
## [1301] "payin' fer deliverin' the paper. Look in the pockets.\" Hagrid's coat"        
## [1302] "seemed to be made of nothing but pockets -- bunches of keys, slug"            
## [1303] "pellets, balls of string, peppermint humbugs, teabags... finally, Harry"      
## [1304] "pulled out a handful of strange-looking coins.　　\"Give him five"            
## [1305] "Knuts,\" said Hagrid sleepily.　　\"Knuts?\"　　\"The little bronze"          
## [1306] "ones.\"　　Harry counted out five little bronze coins, and the owl held"      
## [1307] "out his leg so Harry could put the money into a small leather pouch"          
## [1308] "tied to it. Then he flew off through the open window.　　Hagrid yawned"       
## [1309] "loudly, sat up, and stretched.　　\"Best be Off, Harry, lots ter do"          
## [1310] "today, gotta get up ter London an' buy all yer stuff fer"                     
## [1311] "school.\"　　Harry was turning over the wizard coins and looking at"          
## [1312] "them. He had just thought of something that made him feel as though the"      
## [1313] "happy balloon inside him had got a puncture.　　\"Um --"                      
## [1314] "Hagrid?\"　　\"Mm?\" said Hagrid, who was pulling on his huge boots.　　\"I"  
## [1315] "haven't got any money -- and you heard Uncle Vernon last night ... he"        
## [1316] "won't pay for me to go and learn magic.\"　　\"Don't worry about that,\""     
## [1317] "said Hagrid, standing up and scratching his head. \"D'yeh think yer"          
## [1318] "parents didn't leave yeh anything?\"　　\"But if their house was"             
## [1319] "destroyed --\"　　\"They didn' keep their gold in the house, boy! Nah,"       
## [1320] "first stop fer us is Gringotts. Wizards' bank. Have a sausage, they're"       
## [1321] "not bad cold -- an' I wouldn' say no teh a bit o' yer birthday cake,"         
## [1322] "neither.\"　　\"Wizards have banks?\"　　\"Just the one. Gringotts. Run by"   
## [1323] "goblins.\"　　Harry dropped the bit of sausage he was"                        
## [1324] "holding.　　\"Goblins?\"　　\"Yeah -- so yeh'd be mad ter try an' rob it,"    
## [1325] "I'll tell yeh that. Never mess with goblins, Harry. Gringotts is the"         
## [1326] "safest place in the world fer anything yeh want ter keep safe -- 'cept"       
## [1327] "maybe Hogwarts. As a matter o' fact, I gotta visit Gringotts anyway."         
## [1328] "Fer Dumbledore. Hogwarts business.\" Hagrid drew himself up proudly. \"He"    
## [1329] "usually gets me ter do important stuff fer him. Fetchin' you gettin'"         
## [1330] "things from Gringotts -- knows he can trust me, see.　　\"Got"                
## [1331] "everythin'? Come on, then.\"　　Harry followed Hagrid out onto the rock."     
## [1332] "The sky was quite clear now and the sea gleamed in the sunlight. The"         
## [1333] "boat Uncle Vernon had hired was still there, with a lot of water in the"      
## [1334] "bottom after the storm.　　\"How did you get here?\" Harry asked, looking"    
## [1335] "around for another boat. \"Flew,\" said Hagrid.　　\"Flew?\"　　\"Yeah --"    
## [1336] "but we'll go back in this. Not s'pposed ter use magic now I've got"           
## [1337] "yeh.\"　　They settled down in the boat, Harry still staring at Hagrid,"      
## [1338] "trying to imagine him flying.　　\"Seems a shame ter row, though,\" said"     
## [1339] "Hagrid, giving Harry another of his sideways looks. \"If I was ter -- er"     
## [1340] "-- speed things up a bit, would yeh mind not mentionin' it at"                
## [1341] "Hogwarts?\"　　\"Of course not,\" said Harry, eager to see more magic."       
## [1342] "Hagrid pulled out the pink umbrella again, tapped it twice on the side"       
## [1343] "of the boat, and they sped off toward land.　　\"Why would you be mad to"     
## [1344] "try and rob Gringotts?\" Harry asked.　　\"Spells -- enchantments,\" said"    
## [1345] "Hagrid, unfolding his newspaper as he spoke. \"They say there's dragons"      
## [1346] "guardin' the highsecurity vaults. And then yeh gotta find yer way --"         
## [1347] "Gringotts is hundreds of miles under London, see. Deep under the"             
## [1348] "Underground. Yeh'd die of hunger tryin' ter get out, even if yeh did"         
## [1349] "manage ter get yer hands on summat.\"　　Harry sat and thought about"         
## [1350] "this while Hagrid read his newspaper, the Daily Prophet. Harry had"           
## [1351] "learned from Uncle Vernon that people liked to be left alone while they"      
## [1352] "did this, but it was very difficult, he'd never had so many questions"        
## [1353] "in his life.　　\"Ministry o' Magic messin' things up as usual,\" Hagrid"     
## [1354] "muttered, turning the page.　　\"There's a Ministry of Magic?\" Harry"        
## [1355] "asked, before he could stop himself.　　\"'Course,\" said Hagrid. \"They"     
## [1356] "wanted Dumbledore fer Minister, 0 ' course, but he'd never leave"             
## [1357] "Hogwarts, so old Cornelius Fudge got the job. Bungler if ever there was"      
## [1358] "one. So he pelts Dumbledore with owls every morning, askin' fer"              
## [1359] "advice.\"　　\"But what does a Ministry of Magic do?\"　　\"Well, their"      
## [1360] "main job is to keep it from the Muggles that there's still witches an'"       
## [1361] "wizards up an' down the country.\"　　\"Why?\"　　\"Why? Blimey, Harry,"      
## [1362] "everyone'd be wantin' magic solutions to their problems. Nah, we're"          
## [1363] "best left alone.\"　　At this moment the boat bumped gently into the"         
## [1364] "harbor wall. Hagrid folded up his newspaper, and they clambered up the"       
## [1365] "stone steps onto the street.　　Passersby stared a lot at Hagrid as"          
## [1366] "they walked through the little town to the station. Harry couldn't"           
## [1367] "blame them. Not only was Hagrid twice as tall as anyone else, he kept"        
## [1368] "pointing at perfectly ordinary things like parking meters and saying"         
## [1369] "loudly, \"See that, Harry? Things these Muggles dream up,"                    
## [1370] "eh?\"　　\"Hagrid,\" said Harry, panting a bit as he ran to keep up, \"did"   
## [1371] "you say there are dragons at Gringotts?\"　　\"Well, so they say,\" said"     
## [1372] "Hagrid. \"Crikey, I'd like a dragon.\"　　\"You'd like one?\"　　\"Wanted"    
## [1373] "one ever since I was a kid -- here we go.\"　　They had reached the"          
## [1374] "station. There was a train to London in five minutes' time. Hagrid, who"      
## [1375] "didn't understand \"Muggle money,\" as he called it, gave the bills to"       
## [1376] "Harry so he could buy their tickets.　　People stared more than ever on"      
## [1377] "the train. Hagrid took up two seats and sat knitting what looked like a"      
## [1378] "canary-yellow circus tent.　　\"Still got yer letter, Harry?\" he asked"      
## [1379] "as he counted stitches. Harry took the parchment envelope out of his"         
## [1380] "pocket.　　\"Good,\" said Hagrid. \"There's a list there of everything yeh"   
## [1381] "need.\"　　Harry unfolded a second piece of paper he hadn't noticed the"      
## [1382] "night before, and read:　　HOGWARTS SCHOOL of WITCHCRAFT and"                 
## [1383] "WIZARDRY　　UNIFORM　　First-year students will require:　　1. Three"         
## [1384] "sets of plain work robes (black)　　2. One plain pointed hat (black)"         
## [1385] "for day wear　　3. One pair of protective gloves (dragon hide or"             
## [1386] "similar)　　4. One winter cloak (black, silver fastenings)　　Please"         
## [1387] "note that all pupils' clothes should carry name tags　　COURSE"               
## [1388] "BOOKS　　All students should have a copy of each of the"                      
## [1389] "following:　　The Standard Book of Spells (Grade 1) by Miranda"               
## [1390] "Goshawk　　A History of Magic by Bathilda Bagshot　　Magical Theory by"       
## [1391] "Adalbert Waffling　　A Beginners' Guide to Transfiguration by Emetic"         
## [1392] "Switch　　One Thousand Magical Herbs and Fungi by Phyllida"                   
## [1393] "Spore　　Magical Drafts and Potions by Arsenius Jigger　　Fantastic"          
## [1394] "Beasts and Where to Find Them by Newt Scamander　　The Dark Forces: A"        
## [1395] "Guide to Self-Protection by Quentin Trimble　　OTHER EQUIPMENT　　wand"       
## [1396] "cauldron (pewter, standard size 2) set　　glass or crystal"                   
## [1397] "phials　　telescope set　　brass scales　　Students may also bring an"        
## [1398] "owl OR a cat OR a toad　　PARENTS ARE REMINDED THAT FIRST YEARS ARE NOT"      
## [1399] "ALLOWED THEIR OWN BROOMSTICKS　　\"Can we buy all this in London?\" Harry"    
## [1400] "wondered aloud.　　\"If yeh know where to go,\" said Hagrid.　　Harry had"    
## [1401] "never been to London before. Although Hagrid seemed to know where he"         
## [1402] "was going, he was obviously not used to getting there in an ordinary"         
## [1403] "way. He got stuck in the ticket barrier on the Underground, and"              
## [1404] "complained loudly that the seats were too small and the trains too"           
## [1405] "slow.　　\"I don't know how the Muggles manage without magic,\" he said"      
## [1406] "as they climbed a broken-down escalator that led up to a bustling road"       
## [1407] "lined with shops.　　Hagrid was so huge that he parted the crowd"             
## [1408] "easily; all Harry had to do was keep close behind him. They passed book"      
## [1409] "shops and music stores, hamburger restaurants and cinemas, but nowhere"       
## [1410] "that looked as if it could sell you a magic wand. This was just an"           
## [1411] "ordinary street full of ordinary people. Could there really be piles of"      
## [1412] "wizard gold buried miles beneath them? Were there really shops that"          
## [1413] "sold spell books and broomsticks? Might this not all be some huge joke"       
## [1414] "that the Dursleys had cooked up? If Harry hadn't known that the"              
## [1415] "Dursleys had no sense of humor, he might have thought so; yet somehow,"       
## [1416] "even though everything Hagrid had told him so far was unbelievable,"          
## [1417] "Harry couldn't help trusting him.　　\"This is it,\" said Hagrid, coming"     
## [1418] "to a halt, \"the Leaky Cauldron. It's a famous place.\"　　It was a tiny,"    
## [1419] "grubby-looking pub. If Hagrid hadn't pointed it out, Harry wouldn't"          
## [1420] "have noticed it was there. The people hurrying by didn't glance at it."       
## [1421] "Their eyes slid from the big book shop on one side to the record shop"        
## [1422] "on the other as if they couldn't see the Leaky Cauldron at all. In"           
## [1423] "fact, Harry had the most peculiar feeling that only he and Hagrid could"      
## [1424] "see it. Before he could mention this, Hagrid had steered him"                 
## [1425] "inside.　　For a famous place, it was very dark and shabby. A few old"        
## [1426] "women were sitting in a corner, drinking tiny glasses of sherry. One of"      
## [1427] "them was smoking a long pipe. A little man in a top hat was talking to"       
## [1428] "the old bartender, who was quite bald and looked like a toothless"            
## [1429] "walnut. The low buzz of chatter stopped when they walked in. Everyone"        
## [1430] "seemed to know Hagrid; they waved and smiled at him, and the bartender"       
## [1431] "reached for a glass, saying, \"The usual, Hagrid?\"　　\"Can't, Tom, I'm"     
## [1432] "on Hogwarts business,\" said Hagrid, clapping his great hand on Harry's"      
## [1433] "shoulder and making Harry's knees buckle.　　\"Good Lord,\" said the"         
## [1434] "bartender, peering at Harry, \"is this -- can this be --?\"　　The Leaky"     
## [1435] "Cauldron had suddenly gone completely still and silent.　　\"Bless my"        
## [1436] "soul,\" whispered the old bartender, \"Harry Potter... what an"               
## [1437] "honor.\"　　He hurried out from behind the bar, rushed toward Harry and"      
## [1438] "seized his hand, tears in his eyes.　　\"Welcome back, Mr. Potter,"           
## [1439] "welcome back.\"　　Harry didn't know what to say. Everyone was looking"       
## [1440] "at him. The old woman with the pipe was puffing on it without realizing"      
## [1441] "it had gone out. Hagrid was beaming.　　Then there was a great scraping"      
## [1442] "of chairs and the next moment, Harry found himself shaking hands with"        
## [1443] "everyone in the Leaky Cauldron.　　\"Doris Crockford, Mr. Potter, can't"      
## [1444] "believe I'm meeting you at last.\"　　\"So proud, Mr. Potter, I'm just so"    
## [1445] "proud.\"　　\"Always wanted to shake your hand -- I'm all of a"               
## [1446] "flutter.\"　　\"Delighted, Mr. Potter, just can't tell you, Diggle's the"     
## [1447] "name, Dedalus Diggle.\"　　\"I've seen you before!\" said Harry, as"          
## [1448] "Dedalus Diggle's top hat fell off in his excitement. \"You bowed to me"       
## [1449] "once in a shop.\"　　\"He remembers!\" cried Dedalus Diggle, looking"         
## [1450] "around at everyone. \"Did you hear that? He remembers me!\" Harry shook"      
## [1451] "hands again and again -- Doris Crockford kept coming back for"                
## [1452] "more.　　A pale young man made his way forward, very nervously. One of"       
## [1453] "his eyes was twitching.　　\"Professor Quirrell!\" said Hagrid. \"Harry,"     
## [1454] "Professor Quirrell will be one of your teachers at"                           
## [1455] "Hogwarts.\"　　\"P-P-Potter,\" stammered Professor Quirrell, grasping"        
## [1456] "Harry's hand, \"c-can't t-tell you how p- pleased I am to meet"               
## [1457] "you.\"　　\"What sort of magic do you teach, Professor"                       
## [1458] "Quirrell?\"　　\"D-Defense Against the D-D-Dark Arts,\" muttered Professor"   
## [1459] "Quirrell, as though he'd rather not think about it. \"N-not that you"         
## [1460] "n-need it, eh, P-P-Potter?\" He laughed nervously. \"You'll be g-getting"     
## [1461] "all your equipment, I suppose? I've g-got to p-pick up a new b-book on"       
## [1462] "vampires, m-myself.\" He looked terrified at the very thought.　　But"        
## [1463] "the others wouldn't let Professor Quirrell keep Harry to himself. It"         
## [1464] "took almost ten minutes to get away from them all. At last, Hagrid"           
## [1465] "managed to make himself heard over the babble.　　\"Must get on -- lots"      
## [1466] "ter buy. Come on, Harry.\"　　Doris Crockford shook Harry's hand one"         
## [1467] "last time, and Hagrid led them through the bar and out into a small,"         
## [1468] "walled courtyard, where there was nothing but a trash can and a few"          
## [1469] "weeds.　　Hagrid grinned at Harry.　　\"Told yeh, didn't I? Told yeh you"     
## [1470] "was famous. Even Professor Quirrell was tremblin' ter meet yeh -- mind"       
## [1471] "you, he's usually tremblin'.\"　　\"Is he always that nervous?\"　　\"Oh,"    
## [1472] "yeah. Poor bloke. Brilliant mind. He was fine while he was　　studyin'"       
## [1473] "outta books but then he took a year off ter get some firsthand"               
## [1474] "experience.... They say he met vampires in the Black Forest, and there"       
## [1475] "was a nasty bit o' trouble with a hag -- never been the same since."          
## [1476] "Scared of the students, scared of his own subject now, where's me"            
## [1477] "umbrella?\"　　Vampires? Hags? Harry's head was swimming. Hagrid,"            
## [1478] "meanwhile, was counting bricks in the wall above the trash"                   
## [1479] "can.　　\"Three up... two across he muttered. \"Right, stand back,"           
## [1480] "Harry.\"　　He tapped the wall three times with the point of his"             
## [1481] "umbrella.　　The brick he had touched quivered -- it wriggled -- in the"      
## [1482] "middle, a small hole appeared -- it grew wider and wider -- a second"         
## [1483] "later they were facing an archway large enough even for Hagrid, an"           
## [1484] "archway onto a cobbled street that twisted and turned out of"                 
## [1485] "sight.　　\"Welcome,\" said Hagrid, \"to Diagon Alley.\"　　He grinned at"    
## [1486] "Harry's amazement. They stepped through the archway. Harry looked"            
## [1487] "quickly over his shoulder and saw the archway shrink instantly back"          
## [1488] "into solid wall.　　The sun shone brightly on a stack of cauldrons"           
## [1489] "outside the nearest shop. Cauldrons -- All Sizes - Copper, Brass,"            
## [1490] "Pewter, Silver -- Self-Stirring -- Collapsible, said a sign hanging"          
## [1491] "over them.　　\"Yeah, you'll be needin' one,\" said Hagrid, \"but we gotta"   
## [1492] "get yer money first.\"　　Harry wished he had about eight more eyes. He"      
## [1493] "turned his head in every direction as they walked up the street, trying"      
## [1494] "to look at everything at once: the shops, the things outside them, the"       
## [1495] "people doing their shopping. A plump woman outside an Apothecary was"         
## [1496] "shaking her head as they passed, saying, \"Dragon liver, seventeen"           
## [1497] "Sickles an ounce, they're mad....\"　　A low, soft hooting came from a"       
## [1498] "dark shop with a sign saying Eeylops Owl Emporium -- Tawny, Screech,"         
## [1499] "Barn, Brown, and Snowy. Several boys of about Harry's age had their"          
## [1500] "noses pressed against a window with broomsticks in it. \"Look,\" Harry"       
## [1501] "heard one of them say, \"the new Nimbus Two Thousand -- fastest ever --\""    
## [1502] "There were shops selling robes, shops selling telescopes and strange"         
## [1503] "silver instruments Harry had never seen before, windows stacked with"         
## [1504] "barrels of bat spleens and eels' eyes, tottering piles of spell books,"       
## [1505] "quills, and rolls of parchment, potion bottles, globes of the"                
## [1506] "moon....　　\"Gringotts,\" said Hagrid.　　They had reached a snowy white"    
## [1507] "building that towered over the other little shops. Standing beside its"       
## [1508] "burnished bronze doors, wearing a uniform of scarlet and gold, was"           
## [1509] "-　　\"Yeah, that's a goblin,\" said Hagrid quietly as they walked up the"    
## [1510] "white stone steps toward him. The goblin was about a head shorter than"       
## [1511] "Harry. He had a swarthy, clever face, a pointed beard and, Harry"             
## [1512] "noticed, very long fingers and feet. He bowed as they walked inside."         
## [1513] "Now they were facing a second pair of doors, silver this time, with"          
## [1514] "words engraved upon them:　　Enter, stranger, but take heed　　Of what"       
## [1515] "awaits the sin of greed,　　For those who take, but do not"                   
## [1516] "earn,　　Must pay most dearly in their turn.　　So if you seek beneath"       
## [1517] "our floors　　A treasure that was never yours,　　Thief, you have been"       
## [1518] "warned, beware　　Of finding more than treasure there.　　\"Like I said,"     
## [1519] "Yeh'd be mad ter try an' rob it,\" said Hagrid.　　A pair of goblins"         
## [1520] "bowed them through the silver doors and they were in a vast marble"           
## [1521] "hall. About a hundred more goblins were sitting on high stools behind a"      
## [1522] "long counter, scribbling in large ledgers, weighing coins in brass"           
## [1523] "scales, examining precious stones through eyeglasses. There were too"         
## [1524] "many doors to count leading off the hall, and yet more goblins were"          
## [1525] "showing people in and out of these. Hagrid and Harry made for the"            
## [1526] "counter.　　\"Morning,\" said Hagrid to a free goblin. \"We've come ter"      
## [1527] "take some money outta Mr. Harry Potter's safe.\"　　\"You have his key,"      
## [1528] "Sir?\"　　\"Got it here somewhere,\" said Hagrid, and he started emptying"    
## [1529] "his pockets onto the counter, scattering a handful of moldy dog"              
## [1530] "biscuits over the goblin's book of numbers. The goblin wrinkled his"          
## [1531] "nose. Harry watched the goblin on their right weighing a pile of rubies"      
## [1532] "as big as glowing coals.　　\"Got it,\" said Hagrid at last, holding up a"    
## [1533] "tiny golden key.　　The goblin looked at it closely.　　\"That seems to"      
## [1534] "be in order.\"　　\"An' I've also got a letter here from Professor"           
## [1535] "Dumbledore,\" said Hagrid importantly, throwing out his chest. \"It's"        
## [1536] "about the YouKnow-What in vault seven hundred and thirteen.\"　　The"         
## [1537] "goblin read the letter carefully.　　\"Very well,\" he said, handing it"      
## [1538] "back to Hagrid, \"I will have Someone take you down to both vaults."          
## [1539] "Griphook!\"　　Griphook was yet another goblin. Once Hagrid had crammed"      
## [1540] "all the dog biscuits back inside his pockets, he and Harry followed"          
## [1541] "Griphook toward one of the doors leading off the hall.　　\"What's the"       
## [1542] "You-Know-What in vault seven hundred and thirteen?\" Harry"                   
## [1543] "asked.　　\"Can't tell yeh that,\" said Hagrid mysteriously. \"Very"          
## [1544] "secret. Hogwarts business. Dumbledore's trusted me. More'n my job's"          
## [1545] "worth ter tell yeh that.\"　　Griphook held the door open for them."          
## [1546] "Harry, who had expected more marble, was surprised. They were in a"           
## [1547] "narrow stone passageway lit with flaming torches. It sloped steeply"          
## [1548] "downward and there were little railway tracks on the floor. Griphook"         
## [1549] "whistled and a small cart came hurtling up the tracks toward them. They"      
## [1550] "climbed in -- Hagrid with some difficulty -- and were off.　　At first"       
## [1551] "they just hurtled through a maze of twisting passages. Harry tried to"        
## [1552] "remember, left, right, right, left, middle fork, right, left, but it"         
## [1553] "was impossible. The rattling cart seemed to know its own way, because"        
## [1554] "Griphook wasn't steering.　　Harry's eyes stung as the cold air rushed"       
## [1555] "past them, but he kept them wide open. Once, he thought he saw a burst"       
## [1556] "of fire at the end of a passage and twisted around to see if it was a"        
## [1557] "dragon, but too late - - they plunged even deeper, passing an"                
## [1558] "underground lake where huge stalactites and stalagmites grew from the"        
## [1559] "ceiling and floor.　　I never know,\" Harry called to Hagrid over the"        
## [1560] "noise of the cart, \"what's the difference between a stalagmite and a"        
## [1561] "stalactite?\"　　\"Stalagmite's got an 'm' in it,\" said Hagrid. \"An' don'"  
## [1562] "ask me questions just now, I think I'm gonna be sick.\"　　He did look"       
## [1563] "very green, and when the cart stopped at last beside a small door in"         
## [1564] "the passage wall, Hagrid got out and had to lean against the wall to"         
## [1565] "stop his knees from trembling.　　Griphook unlocked the door. A lot of"       
## [1566] "green smoke came billowing out, and as it cleared, Harry gasped. Inside"      
## [1567] "were mounds of gold coins. Columns of silver. Heaps of little bronze"         
## [1568] "Knuts.　　\"All yours,\" smiled Hagrid.　　All Harry's -- it was"             
## [1569] "incredible. The Dursleys couldn't have known about this or they'd have"       
## [1570] "had it from him faster than blinking. How often had they complained how"      
## [1571] "much Harry cost them to keep? And all the time there had been a small"        
## [1572] "fortune belonging to him, buried deep under London.　　Hagrid helped"         
## [1573] "Harry pile some of it into a bag.　　\"The gold ones are Galleons,\" he"      
## [1574] "explained. \"Seventeen silver Sickles to a Galleon and twenty-nine Knuts"     
## [1575] "to a Sickle, it's easy enough. Right, that should be enough fer a"            
## [1576] "couple o' terms, we'll keep the rest safe for yeh.\" He turned to"            
## [1577] "Griphook. \"Vault seven hundred and thirteen now, please, and can we go"      
## [1578] "more slowly?\"　　\"One speed only,\" said Griphook.　　They were going"      
## [1579] "even deeper now and gathering speed. The air became colder and colder"        
## [1580] "as they hurtled round tight corners. They went rattling over an"              
## [1581] "underground ravine, and Harry leaned over the side to try to see what"        
## [1582] "was down at the dark bottom, but Hagrid groaned and pulled him back by"       
## [1583] "the scruff of his neck.　　Vault seven hundred and thirteen had no"           
## [1584] "keyhole.　　\"Stand back,\" said Griphook importantly. He stroked the"        
## [1585] "door gently with one of his long fingers and it simply melted"                
## [1586] "away.　　\"If anyone but a Gringotts goblin tried that, they'd be sucked"     
## [1587] "through the door and trapped in there,\" said Griphook.　　\"How often do"    
## [1588] "you check to see if anyone's inside?\" Harry asked.　　\"About once every"    
## [1589] "ten years,\" said Griphook with a rather nasty grin.　　Something really"     
## [1590] "extraordinary had to be inside this top security vault, Harry was sure,"      
## [1591] "and he leaned forward eagerly, expecting to see fabulous jewels at the"       
## [1592] "very least -- but at first he thought it was empty. Then he noticed a"        
## [1593] "grubby little package wrapped up in brown paper lying on the floor."          
## [1594] "Hagrid picked it up and tucked it deep inside his coat. Harry longed to"      
## [1595] "know what it was, but knew better than to ask.　　\"Come on, back in"         
## [1596] "this infernal cart, and don't talk to me on the way back, it's best if"       
## [1597] "I keep me mouth shut,\" said Hagrid.　　One wild cart ride later they"        
## [1598] "stood blinking in the sunlight outside Gringotts. Harry didn't know"          
## [1599] "where to run first now that he had a bag full of money. He didn't have"       
## [1600] "to know how many Galleons there were to a pound to know that he was"          
## [1601] "holding more money than he'd had in his whole life -- more money than"        
## [1602] "even Dudley had ever had.　　\"Might as well get yer uniform,\" said"         
## [1603] "Hagrid, nodding toward Madam Malkin's Robes for All Occasions. \"Listen,"     
## [1604] "Harry, would yeh mind if I slipped off fer a pick-me-up in the Leaky"         
## [1605] "Cauldron? I hate them Gringotts carts.\" He did still look a bit sick,"       
## [1606] "so Harry entered Madam Malkin's shop alone, feeling nervous.　　Madam"        
## [1607] "Malkin was a squat, smiling witch dressed all in mauve.　　\"Hogwarts,"       
## [1608] "clear?\" she said, when Harry started to speak. \"Got the lot here --"        
## [1609] "another young man being fitted up just now, in fact. \"　　In the back"       
## [1610] "of the shop, a boy with a pale, pointed face was standing on a"               
## [1611] "footstool while a second witch pinned up his long black robes. Madam"         
## [1612] "Malkin stood Harry on a stool next to him) slipped a long robe over his"      
## [1613] "head, and began to pin it to the right length.　　\"Hello,\" said the"        
## [1614] "boy, \"Hogwarts, too?\"　　\"Yes,\" said Harry.　　\"My father's next door"   
## [1615] "buying my books and mother's up the street looking at wands,\" said the"      
## [1616] "boy. He had a bored, drawling voice. \"Then I'm going to drag them off"       
## [1617] "to took at racing brooms. I don't see why first years can't have their"       
## [1618] "own. I think I'll bully father into getting me one and I'll smuggle it"       
## [1619] "in somehow.\"　　Harry was strongly reminded of Dudley.　　\"Have you got"    
## [1620] "your own broom?\" the boy went on.　　\"No,\" said Harry.　　\"Play"          
## [1621] "Quidditch at all?\"　　\"No,\" Harry said again, wondering what on earth"     
## [1622] "Quidditch could be.　　\"I do -- Father says it's a crime if I'm not"         
## [1623] "picked to play for my house, and I must say, I agree. Know what house"        
## [1624] "you'll be in yet?\"　　\"No,\" said Harry, feeling more stupid by the"        
## [1625] "minute.　　\"Well, no one really knows until they get there, do they,"        
## [1626] "but I know I'll be in Slytherin, all our family have been -- imagine"         
## [1627] "being in Hufflepuff, I think I'd leave, wouldn't you?\" \"Mmm,\" said"        
## [1628] "Harry, wishing he could say something a bit more interesting.　　\"I"         
## [1629] "say, look at that man!\" said the boy suddenly, nodding toward the front"     
## [1630] "window. Hagrid was standing there, grinning at Harry and pointing at"         
## [1631] "two large ice creams to show he couldn't come in.　　\"That's Hagrid,\""      
## [1632] "said Harry, pleased to know something the boy didn't. \"He works at"          
## [1633] "Hogwarts.\"　　\"Oh,\" said the boy, \"I've heard of him. He's a sort of"     
## [1634] "servant, isn't he?\"　　\"He's the gamekeeper,\" said Harry. He was liking"   
## [1635] "the boy less and less every second.　　\"Yes, exactly. I heard he's a"        
## [1636] "sort of savage -- lives in a hut on the school grounds and every now"         
## [1637] "and then he gets drunk, tries to do magic, and ends up setting fire to"       
## [1638] "his bed.\"　　\"I think he's brilliant,\" said Harry coldly.　　\"Do you?\""  
## [1639] "said the boy, with a slight sneer. \"Why is he with you? Where are your"      
## [1640] "parents?\"　　\"They're dead,\" said Harry shortly. He didn't feel much"      
## [1641] "like going into the matter with this boy.　　\"Oh, sorry,\" said the"         
## [1642] "other,. not sounding sorry at all. \"But they were our kind, weren't"         
## [1643] "they?\"　　\"They were a witch and wizard, if that's what you"                
## [1644] "mean.\"　　\"I really don't think they should let the other sort in, do"      
## [1645] "you? They're just not the same, they've never been brought up to know"        
## [1646] "our ways. Some of them have never even heard of Hogwarts until they get"      
## [1647] "the letter, imagine. I think they should keep it in the old wizarding"        
## [1648] "families. What's your surname, anyway?\"　　But before Harry could"           
## [1649] "answer, Madam Malkin said, \"That's you done, my dear,\" and Harry, not"      
## [1650] "sorry for an excuse to stop talking to the boy, hopped down from the"         
## [1651] "footstool.　　\"Well, I'll see you at Hogwarts, I suppose,\" said the"        
## [1652] "drawling boy.　　Harry was rather quiet as he ate the ice cream Hagrid"       
## [1653] "had bought him (chocolate and raspberry with chopped nuts).　　\"What's"      
## [1654] "up?\" said Hagrid.　　\"Nothing,\" Harry lied. They stopped to buy"           
## [1655] "parchment and quills. Harry cheered up a bit when he found a bottle of"       
## [1656] "ink that changed color as you wrote. When they had left the shop, he"         
## [1657] "said, \"Hagrid, what's Quidditch?\"　　\"Blimey, Harry, I keep forgettin'"    
## [1658] "how little yeh know -- not knowin' about Quidditch!\"　　\"Don't make me"     
## [1659] "feel worse,\" said Harry. He told Hagrid about the pate boy in Madam"         
## [1660] "Malkin's.　　\"--and he said people from Muggle families shouldn't even"      
## [1661] "be allowed in.\"　　\"Yer not from a Muggle family. If he'd known who yeh"    
## [1662] "were -- he's grown up knowin' yer name if his parents are wizardin'"          
## [1663] "folk. You saw what everyone in the Leaky Cauldron was like when they"         
## [1664] "saw yeh. Anyway, what does he know about it, some o' the best I ever"         
## [1665] "saw were the only ones with magic in 'em in a long line 0' Muggles --"        
## [1666] "look at yer mum! Look what she had fer a sister!\"　　\"So what is"           
## [1667] "Quidditch?\"　　\"It's our sport. Wizard sport. It's like -- like soccer"     
## [1668] "in the Muggle world -- everyone follows Quidditch -- played up in the"        
## [1669] "air on broomsticks and there's four balls -- sorta hard ter explain the"      
## [1670] "rules.\" \"And what are Slytherin and Hufflepuff?\"　　\"School houses."      
## [1671] "There's four. Everyone says Hufflepuff are a lot o' duffers, but"             
## [1672] "--\"　　\"I bet I'm in Hufflepuff\" said Harry gloomily.　　\"Better"         
## [1673] "Hufflepuff than Slytherin,\" said Hagrid darkly. \"There's not a single"      
## [1674] "witch or wizard who went bad who wasn't in Slytherin. You-Know-Who was"       
## [1675] "one.\"　　\"Vol-, sorry - You-Know-Who was at Hogwarts?\"　　\"Years an'"     
## [1676] "years ago,\" said Hagrid.　　They bought Harry's school books in a shop"      
## [1677] "called Flourish and Blotts where the shelves were stacked to the"             
## [1678] "ceiling with books as large as paving stones bound in leather; books"         
## [1679] "the size of postage stamps in covers of silk; books full of peculiar"         
## [1680] "symbols and a few books with nothing in them at all. Even Dudley, who"        
## [1681] "never read anything, would have been wild to get his hands on some of"        
## [1682] "these. Hagrid almost had to drag Harry away from Curses and"                  
## [1683] "Countercurses (Bewitch Your Friends and Befuddle Your Enemies with the"       
## [1684] "Latest Revenges: Hair Loss, Jelly-Legs, Tongue- Tying and Much, Much"         
## [1685] "More) by Professor Vindictus Viridian.　　\"I was trying to find out how"     
## [1686] "to curse Dudley.\"　　\"I'm not sayin' that's not a good idea, but yer"       
## [1687] "not ter use magic in the Muggle world except in very special"                 
## [1688] "circumstances,\" said Hagrid. \"An' anyway, yeh couldn' work any of them"     
## [1689] "curses yet, yeh'll need a lot more study before yeh get ter that"             
## [1690] "level.\"　　Hagrid wouldn't let Harry buy a solid gold cauldron, either"      
## [1691] "(\"It says pewter on yer list\"), but they got a nice set of scales for"      
## [1692] "weighing potion ingredients and a collapsible brass telescope. Then"          
## [1693] "they visited the Apothecary, which was fascinating enough to make up"         
## [1694] "for its horrible smell, a mixture of bad eggs and rotted cabbages."           
## [1695] "Barrels of slimy stuff stood on the floor; jars of herbs, dried roots,"       
## [1696] "and bright powders lined the walls; bundles of feathers, strings of"          
## [1697] "fangs, and snarled claws hung from the ceiling. While Hagrid asked the"       
## [1698] "man behind the counter for a supply of some basic potion ingredients"         
## [1699] "for Harry, Harry himself examined silver unicorn horns at twenty-one"         
## [1700] "Galleons each and minuscule, glittery-black beetle eyes (five Knuts a"        
## [1701] "scoop).　　Outside the Apothecary, Hagrid checked Harry's list"               
## [1702] "again.　　\"Just yer wand left - A yeah, an' I still haven't got yeh a"       
## [1703] "birthday present.\"　　Harry felt himself go red.　　\"You don't have to"     
## [1704] "--\"　　\"I know I don't have to. Tell yeh what, I'll get yer animal. Not"    
## [1705] "a toad, toads went outta fashion years ago, yeh'd be laughed at - an' I"      
## [1706] "don' like cats, they make me sneeze. I'll get yer an owl. All the kids"       
## [1707] "want owls, they're dead useful, carry yer mail an'"                           
## [1708] "everythin'.\"　　Twenty minutes later, they left Eeylops Owl Emporium,"       
## [1709] "which had been dark and full of rustling and flickering, jewel-bright"        
## [1710] "eyes. Harry now carried a large cage that held a beautiful snowy owl,"        
## [1711] "fast asleep with her head under her wing. He couldn't stop stammering"        
## [1712] "his thanks, sounding just like Professor Quirrell.　　\"Don' mention"         
## [1713] "it,\" said Hagrid gruffly. \"Don' expect you've had a lotta presents from"    
## [1714] "them Dursleys. Just Ollivanders left now - only place fer wands,"             
## [1715] "Ollivanders, and yeh gotta have the best wand.\"　　A magic wand... this"     
## [1716] "was what Harry had been really looking forward to.　　The last shop was"      
## [1717] "narrow and shabby. Peeling gold letters over the door read Ollivanders:"      
## [1718] "Makers of Fine Wands since 382 B.C. A single wand lay on a faded purple"      
## [1719] "cushion in the dusty window.　　A tinkling bell rang somewhere in the"        
## [1720] "depths of the shop as they stepped inside. It was a tiny place, empty"        
## [1721] "except for a single, spindly chair that Hagrid sat on to wait. Harry"
